title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in various subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in various subsections, including district courts of the United States or any United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in various subsections, including district courts or courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows for foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. A Federal judge may issue orders to execute requests from foreign authorities for assistance in criminal offenses. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions, including search warrants, warrants for electronic communications, and orders for testimony or document production. Federal judges can appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, administer oaths, and receive documents. Requests for assistance from foreign authorities can be filed under this section. Federal judges can appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. Requests for assistance from foreign authorities can be filed in specific districts or in cases related to a federal criminal investigation. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the appropriate district. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year. Orders or warrants issued can be served anywhere in the United States, except as provided in subsection (d). Foreign authorities or interested persons can seek assistance in criminal investigations under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. Foreign authorities or interested persons can seek assistance in criminal investigations under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code, without precluding assistance from foreign authorities. Definitions for "Federal judge" and "attorney for the Government" are provided, as well as the term "foreign authority" which includes various entities responsible for criminal investigations or prosecutions. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions can be made under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code.
